text: The attached letter is from Richard LeVasseur, President of the Jo Mary Riders Snowmobile Club near Millinocket, Maine. It's about the Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument and the need for it to be "left alone".

Dear Secretary ZInke,

I already submitted written comments on Bear's Ears and plan to submit a detailed letter on the Grand Staircase Escalante National Monument before the comment deadline of July 10. We have been visiting the Grand Staircase Escalante region since the early 1990s, before it was designated a National Monument. In the meantime, I wanted to share with you our recent letter to the editor regarding the Grand Staircase and Bear's Ears that was printed in High Country News and shares my and my husband's view of the impact of Monument designations on local communities.

I live in a rural area of California (the Eastern Sierra region) and I know very well the impact special land designations can have on the economy and nearby communities. I live in Lee Vining, CA adjacent to the Mono Basin National Forest Scenic Area, which was designated in 1984 amid local controversy. I moved here in 1984 just before the designation, and have witnessed the transformation of our town in the years since the designation (during that time I served for 16 years on the Mono County Planning Commission). Today, Lee Vining is a thriving community from late spring through the fall (when mountain passes are open) and an international destination for tourists. While there will always be disagreements over precisely how a piece of public land is managed, no one disputes the economic benefits the Scenic Area designation brought not only to our community but to our County, Mono County.

I hope you will retain the Grand Staircase Escalante National Monument designation in full, and not undo years of investment in protecting these landscapes for the benefit of all the people, including those who live in nearby communities.

Thank you for considering my written comments today, and those contained in our letter to the editor.

Sincerely,
Sally Miller
Lee Vining, CA 93541

docAbstract: This rulemaking would amend the NRC's regulations to add new emergency preparedness requirements for small modular reactors and other new technologies such as non-light-water reactors and non-power production or utilization facilities. The rule would adopt a scalable plume exposure pathway emergency planning zone approach that is performance-based, consequence-oriented, and technology-inclusive. This rulemaking would affect applicants for new NRC licenses and reduce regulatory burden related to the exemption process.

text:
I live on the Olympic Peninsula in Washington State, where our economic and spiritual survival depends on
sound environmental protection policies. As a former commercial fisherman in Alaska, I chose to live here because of its proximity to wildlife reserves and wildlife habitats, the salmon runs and the historic removal of the Elwha dam, which is returning salmon to the Elwha river. Our salmon runs support commercial and sport fishing industries and provide an important cultural resource for our First Nations people. An equally integral contributor to the economic survival of the
Peninsula is tourism. Without the EPA to serve as a vigilant protector against clean air and clean water violators, illegal logging, and violations of wildlife and wildlife habitat protection we stand to lose the economic and spiritual heartbeat that gives life to our region. Please don't gut the regulations that have protected these valuable economic and spiritual resources; we need them now more than ever. They are part of our national heritage and identity and it would be a grave error to sacrifice them--and the jobs they support-- in a misguided effort to save money. Though it was written in 1960, Wallace Stegner's eloquent, impassioned plea for wilderness is even more relevant and urgent today. I attach it here for your consideration.

text: Secretary Pruitt--I support commonsense regulations for clean air and water.  Too many operatives in the extraction and power industries short cut commonsense measures and end up causing harm to citizens who live within their scope of influence.  Uranium mining outfits have left radioactive dumps that have sickened Native Americans particularly on the Navajo and Hopi Reservations.  Coal mining operations and coal burning power plants have fouled drinking water with coal ash and the air with mercury.  The EPA should not be an enabler of corporate crime and negligence.  Pipelines always leak and sometimes explode, fracking operations are causing water pollution, earthquakes.  It is blatantly obvious that industries are more than willing to sacrifice safety for profit and require regulation in the public benefit.

text:
I feel we need stronger regulations and the necessary staff to be sure the rules are being followed. Taking away or lessening regulations will only weaken what we have worked so hard for when it comes to clean air, water and soil. Business should not be allowed to pollute to make a buck which in the end comes out of tax payers pockets and health. Weakening or eliminating regulations would be taking many steps backward instead of going forward.

If states are the only ones protecting the air and water from polluters, many of the state's citizens would be in a losing situation. Our health is more important than businesses being able to skirt regulations to make more money. For the most part, jobs were lost due to technology, not due to regulations, and if those who would not follow the regulations did poorly in business, then perhaps they should have not been in business to begin with.

With the rising populations in all corners of the world, we need to find solutions and work with what we have and what we have already done. Without regulations, or weakened ones, our children and their children will grow up in a world we barely got out of and to head us back into using dangerous pesticides & chemicals, increase in pollution from vehicles, polluting smokestacks and lead in our water and paint....it would be dishonor to those who have worked so hard before us. We look to your agency for guidance and governance which is extremely important and necessary. Please lead us forward into a cleaner and healthier planet.

text:
The EPA was created by Republican president Richard Nixon to "permit coordinated and effective government action on behalf of the environment." Fifteen different environmental programs from various federal offices were included under EPA.

Decreasing the regulatory burden (of the EPA) is a concept that--as it is being used--is ignorant of not only the intent and purpose of the EPA, but of the risks and dangers of modern civilization.

It is imperative that the most recent and robust science is used to continue to carry out the mission of the EPA. And that this agency continue its mission to protect our environment!

text:
Please follow the precautionary principal in all decisions. Do not ever consider jobs or corporations over the environmental health and public health ramifications of decisions. Our first priority shall be to do no harm. Our second prioroity shall be to correct pass harms done and clean up our air, water, land and environment.

All EPA rules that in any way protect our natural or human environment shall be upheld and shall only be considred if made more protective.

text: Clean air, clean water, clean soil - these three things are necessary to help Americans (and all people) be able to live healthy, productive lives. We need clean air so we can breathe (bad pollution is linked to increased asthma, which can be deadly). We need clean water so that we can drink it - water is vital to life. And clean soil is necessary to help agriculture, and keep our water supply clean. This is our planet - we only have one. The EPA needs to help safeguard these things, which impact every aspect of life - and impact every American. PLEASE PROTECT OUR ENVIRONMENT! It is the EPA's duty to support all Americans by protecting our environment.

text:
Dear Mr. Pruitt,
I'm writing to you today to express my dismay at your plan to dismantle the EPA and the regulations that safeguard our health and the environment. I find it particularly disturbing that you've been put in charge of an agency that you regard with such contempt. I understand that President Trump put you in charge so that you would do his bidding and the bidding of the fossil fuel industry. It's clear that both of you gentlemen have no use for environmental regulations or safeguards. Well, I can tell you this. We Americans will not stand by and watch you take down the agency that's supposed to protect the environment just so you can line the pockets of the richest people in the country, the fossil fuel barons. We will be watching and we implore you to do the right thing by keeping environmental safeguards in place that will ensure the health of our environment and our people. I expect that when it comes right down to it, you will do what's right. Please don't disappoint us because we will not stand for it. Thanks for your consideration on this issue.

Sincerely,
Adam R. D'Onofrio

text:
The EPA was formed in 1970, under a Republican, Richard Nixon, and there was a reason for it. That reason has not gone away or even diminished. Although the agency has done a lot to improve our air and water quality, there remains much to be done to keep up with the changing circumstances and needs of our country and world.

These are not things that can be left to individual states, as both air and water, not to mention other facets of our environment that come under the agency's purview, are not bound by state (or country, for that matter) boundaries. Just as the toxic herbicides that one farmer uses on his/her fields will drift into neighboring fields via the air and groundwater, the pollution that one state allows to be dumped into its rivers or air will ultimately find its way to neighboring states, undermining any attempts those states may make to protect their environment.

It is the responsibility of the government to protect us, the people, and that includes protecting us from the questionable decisions of some that have adverse effects on others. The country can only be as strong as its people, and its people cannot be strong if their bodies are constantly under attack from a polluted environment.

Thank you for seriously, objectively considering my comments.

text:
Years of thoughtful policy review have given us the environmental protection currently in place. They safeguard or water supply and the air we breathe. Cutting these policies or gutting them via lack of enforcement threatens all Americans. The EPA protect our public lands for all Americans. Stepping away from environmental protection allows unscrupulous people to take advantage of our great nation, all in the guise of enabling business.

We can do both -- enable business AND protect the environment we all depend on. Requiring oversight and accountability is the only way to ensure that businesses don't pollute our water sources and atmosphere.

Please oppose rolling back the EPA's mission.

text:
The real agenda behind executive order 13777 is reflected in its Orwellian wording:
"in order to lower regulatory burdens on the American people". Pres. Trump couldn't care less about "the American people". The administration has been clear in its all-out support for a kind of capitalism which has as its only priority financial gains for already-rich corporations and individuals. This cabal of the one percent, by the one percent, and for the one percent is sure to undervalue the health of the majority of citizens as well as that of the earth itself as it goes about the process of eliminating restrictions on big business that in most cases are the only protections the public has.
Until we can progress toward a solid body of laws regarding what corporations can and cannot do, we should be very wary of what these foxes in the henhouse do to the regulatory framework.
docAbstract: Executive Order 13777, issued 2/24/17, directs agencies to establish a Regulatory Reform Task Force to oversee the evaluation of existing regulations to make recommendations about potential repeal, replacement, or modification.

text:
A strong and well-funded EPA provides essential restoration from past environmental assaults, as well as protection for the future of our very fragile and complex environment. The grand scope of this issue requires a national focus and effort. I oppose any attempt to cut back on programs that help to solve the problems that currently threaten the health of people and our land, air, and water.

The EPA's Superfund Program, applying best practice science as a standard for site cleanup projects, must continue to be fully funded.

We need to restore the Clean Power Plan and promote efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions from power plants and other major sources. The EPA must continue to promote renewable energy and energy efficiency as tools for now and for the future. Robust standards must remain in place for clean energy development and non-polluting vehicles. These industries can provide thousands of jobs and help to revitalize our economy.

The Energy Star program has been a resounding success. It has had a huge impact in money saved on utility bills and reduction in emissions of greenhouse gases, benefiting both consumers and the environment. The program must be preservednot cut or eliminated. The fact that Trump buildings have low E-star ratings is an outrage. He is setting a lousy example for other Americans.

text: Please don't remove any regulations; we need all of them to protect our environment, health, and natural resources.  Please don't take us back to a time before a Republican president, Richard Nixon, created the EPA, in 1970.  That was a time when Republicans believed in science and conservation.  Far more jobs can be created that work within EPA guidelines than that work against them; they are called "green jobs." text:
I've lived in the Great Lakes region my entire life, first in Minnesota on Superior, now in northern Indiana near Lake Michigan. I was watching with horror as the first draft of the budget was projected to cut EPA funding for my region almost in its entirety. This as the city of East Chicago is experiencing a lead water crisis. This as northern Indiana struggles to hang on to economic vibrancy by tapping into the tourism market supplied by the Dunes and other incredibly beautiful federal- and state-protected land.
I've seen the water of the Grand Calumet River literally set on fire. I've had friends get chemical burns from working in that river. The EPA is cleaning it up, and supplying grants to those of us doing the work of environmental restoration. That means jobs and lots of them.
If the decision-makers reading this would like a projection of what my home, let alone this entire country, will look like under a weakened EPA, examples sadly abound here and worldwide. Come to East Chicago and run someone's tap - but be careful not to drink. Walk the industrialized miles of the Lakeshore, but stay clear of the chromium-laden surf. Visit Beijing, but be sure to bring your particle mask.

And please, think about how your decisions will impact those of us young enough to live with their fallout.
Thank you,
- Bria Fleming

text:
Dear EPA,

Please do not roll back the all-important regulations surrounding our clean air, water, and soil. In order to protect the health and safety of all Americans and world citizens and in the future, we need to strengthen these regulations, not dismantle them. Coal and oil are the energies of the past and should be put in their place. Corporations should pay a price for the pollution they cause, but that price should not be the health and well-being of our citizens. Do not let politics get in the way of what you know is right for our future and for our children. Do not put a greater burden on future generations to clean up the mess of the past. We should be providing our children with a better world in which to live, and these regulations are necessary to do so.
docAbstract: Executive Order 13777, issued 2/24/17, directs agencies to establish a Regulatory Reform Task Force to oversee the evaluation of existing regulations to make recommendations about potential repeal, replacement, or modification.

text:
The EPA is the greatest innovation this century and its protections have improved our water, air, human and environmental health. The EPA provides safeguards to ensure quality of life when industrial altruism is unreliable. The EPA exists to protect citizens of the USA, and to avoid conflicts with entities that have profit as their principal goal.
The EPA should be strengthened, not weakened, and provide platform for sound science, recommend strict protections for environmental issues, especially climate change. The US public needs to have confidence that our Federal Agencies are working on behalf of the health and welfare of all our citizens and serve as an international model for rational, science evidence based environment protections.
We should maintain our parks, monuments and other public lands intact and with only sustainable use, recreation and spiritual renewal. Our biodiversity needs strong protection as we face a human cause extinction crises eliminating species at many time the background rate.
In this day and age, we must be extra vigilant on water,air, climate change and species extinction and I expect serious proactive service and not denial from
the EPA in coordination with other agencies. These issues are at the core of national security, environmental security,
economic security and the future of life on this planet. We have no time to waste, and need to be proactive and vigilant.
AA a US citizen and voter, father and ecologist, I will
do all that I can to ensure a strong EPA.

text: Our country has a long and ugly history of people and businesses believing it's ok for them to pollute public waterways, lands, and air for their personal short-term profit. The EPA's regulations are the ONLY way to protect all Americans' health and safety--and it's PROVEN effectiveness and success must not be disregarded! Do NOT weaken the ability of the federal government to safeguard the very resources humans need for health and life. We have been there before--do not return us to that same awful place.

text:
Regulations that protect the environment and public health should be strengthened and advanced. The EPA is charged to protect the environment and should not act as the 'Polluter's Protection Agency'.

Pruitt states, "We are supporting the restoration of America's economy through extensive reviews of the misaligned regulatory actions from the past administration". However, an attempt to roll back the regulations associated with the Clean Power Plan, for example, will burden the growing the U.S. clean energy industry, an industry which has potential to provide domestically produced power on par with current fossil fuel energy production and do so with lower costs and fewer negative health and environmental impacts. The economy Pruitt wants to "restore" doesn't just include the bottom line of industry but the far reaching negative impacts of pollution on the safety and security of the American public.

The coal industry alone is responsible for extensive negative impacts on human health and the environment and regulations to limit these negative effects need to be strengthened. Extracting, processing and burning coal causes environmental degradation and pollution from particulates, carbon monoxide, sulfur dioxide, ozone, heavy metals, benzene, radionuclides, mercury, and acid deposition. There are a number of negative health effects of coal that occur through its mining, preparation, combustion, waste storage, and transport. Negative health effects from coal use within the U.S. include reduction in life expectancy, health and quality of life; black lung from coal dust; congestive heart failure; non-fatal cancer; osteroporosia; ataxia; renal dysfunction; chronic bronchitis; asthma attacks; loss of IQ from air and water pollution; nervous system damage; global warming, methane; and ecosystem loss and degradation. (Union of Concerned Scienctists - http://www.ucsusa.org/clean_energy/coalvswind/brief_coal.html#.WPtXFY7SY00)

Regarding the criteria for reviewing regulations that eliminate jobs or inhibit job creation: Economic growth for the US is in clean energy, clean water and other green technologies, not in polluting and carbon-based industries. The fossil fuel industries (coal, oil, gas) employ fewer people than the solar industry. (Bloomberg https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-05-25/clean-energy-jobs-surpass-oil-drilling-for-first-time-in-u-s) Solar and other clean energy jobs are growing in the US and abroad. There are over 8 million solar energy jobs worldwide, and solar jobs are projected to grow to 24 million in 2030. EPA regulations should protect the environment and support the economic benefits of clean energy simultaneously.

text:
I have always looked to the EPA as the stronghold that will keep citizens safe from pollution and toxins in our environment. I do not see the agency as a place to find COST CUTTING measures that will undermine the health and safety of the public, waterways, oceans, or land. This office should be the first line of defense against companies and organization that do not consider health and safety as a priority. Your priority should be the civilians who have no other governmental advocate. Your job is NOT to side with companies for profit but to legislate safe practices that will allow the public to live safety without fear of a drop in regulations that allow companies to profit from pollution.

I had a grandfather who died at the age of 36 from benzine poisoning from gasoline before there were any restrictions or safety compliance requirements. This left my grandmother to raise her two young sons age 6 and 8 by herself. This would not happen today thanks in part to EPA regulations. We are not at a place in our nations history to cut these important jobs. WE are trying to create jobs to KEEP AMERICA GREAT. We need this organization strong to keep our people safe from harm without lowering current standards of safety.

text:
As you evaluate existing regulations at the EPA, I urge you to consider how these provisions PROTECT citizens rather than how they might limit certain corporate interests. It seems the priorities in this proposal are backwards. With the the threats to clean water, the dangers of pesticides (I am appalled that Dow was permitted to market a pesticide that has been PROVEN to be damaging to children's cognitive development), and the dangers of climate change, the priority of the EPA should be to improve and protect lives through preventing further damage to the environment, not to help businesses increase their bottom lines at our expense. Such protection is the aim of many of the regulations/protections the Trump administration seems intent on dismantling.

Over my twenty-plus years of teaching I have seen a significant increase in learning and behavioral issues, and there seems to be evidence that environmental degradation has played some part in these changes. For the future of our children, I urge you to take seriously your mission to protect the environment, even if it means that multi-billion dollar industries must sacrifice some profit. I am sure that such businesses can adapt to the changes demanded by the threats to our environment and the need to protect the health and safety of our citizens.

Sincerely,
Terry Kuhlmann

text: I am a scientist who studies the interactions of air pollution and climate change. I strongly oppose the repeal, replacement, or modification of the Clean Power Plan. Not only does the Clean Power Plan reduce carbon dioxide emissions, many other pollutants are simultaneously reduced, including mercury and nitrogen oxides. Thus the co-benefits of reducing greenhouse gases go far beyond simply slowing atmospheric warming. A recent study by Buonocore et al in Nature Climate Change show large economic savings from the Clean Power Plan by preventing hospital and other health costs from people with respiratory ailments. Mercury bioaccumulates in aquatic food chains and people who eat fish with high mercury concentrations concentrations can have serious impacts to nervous, digestive, and immune systems.

text:
The federal government as well as states have meaningful roles to play in protecting the human health and the environment. The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), as the federal government's primary enforcer of environmental laws, plays the most important role in regulating industry to the benefit of the greater good.

Environmental regulations specify the procedures for carrying out laws such as the Clean Air Act, Clean Water Act, RCRA, TSCA, CERCLA, EPCRA, FIFRA, etc., creating even playing fields for businesses and giving those which voluntarily carry out best practices an incentive to keep doing so. Subsequently, businesses that cheat the law run the risk of civil penalties or criminal prosecution. Does this in the end make regulations good for business and good for jobs? There is strong evidence that an even playing field for businesses encourages competition and a race to the top, rather than a race to the bottom. Every dollar spent on enforcement, environmental remediation, and compliance assistance directly contributes to the creation of jobs. The billions of dollars saved in health care costs through protecting human health keeps more money in peoples' pockets and contributes to a vibrate and healthy economy.

What then, is the role for states? States serve as valuable partners for the EPA in the implementation of environmental laws and regulations. Some states even push for greater environmental protections, creating a race to the top among states, however, without EPA as a federal backstop, states would be much more likely to race to the bottom. Much of the budgets of state environmental agencies come through EPA grants. States have the advantage of being closer to problems and being able to tailor more localized solutions. However, states are also closer linked to industry within their localities and are often more timid at enforcement. EPA is much more well suited to enforce in cases in which the state is hesitant or unwilling to act on behalf of protecting its citizens. EPA also has the advantage of being able to act across state lines, as often environmental problems do no respect political boundaries. Similarly, businesses whose operations span several states can be more efficiently regulated at the federal level.

In summation, you cannot evaluate the effectiveness of regulations through purely numerical terms, as simply reducing the number of regulations does not necessarily make government more efficient. Instead, the impacts of regulations must be properly weighed in terms of costs and benefits, taking into full account the positive aspects of protecting human health as well as the negative aspect of potential inefficiencies. Thus, regulations which protect human health but contain inefficiencies should only be replaced with regulations that simultaneously protect human health to the same or higher degree as well as increase efficiency.

text:
The EPA was created in response to corporate catastrophes that did significant damage to the environment, which impacted the lives of all types of beings--plants, animals, and humans. To turn back the clock and undo those accomplishments would put such lives in jeopardy again. That is unacceptable. The EPA has led the way in protecting The Commons--those things we all need to live, namely, clean air, clean water, clean land. Although many corporations have already invested in the infrastructure to protect The Commons, there are those that, given the chance, would gladly take advantage of relaxed regulations, thereby endangering The Commons. Plenty of companies have shown that they can be good stewards of the environment AND make a profit. It is not an either/or game. Keep the regulations that serve to protect The Commons, and hence, Us, the People. Do not just repeal them because businesses have paid you off, paid off the President, or paid off other lawmakers. Do what is Right, for all of us now, and for all of our children and grandchildren.

Consider what could happen if you repeal the Clean Air Act. There is already nearly an epidemic of asthma among children in some communities. Air pollution has been shown to cause a wide variety of adverse health outcomes, not just asthma. If more people are exposed to higher levels of pollutants, then the health of many Americans will suffer, which will put added burden on the health care system. The health care system is already in a fragile state. Given what the Administration wants to do to health care, combined with causing more health problems by repealing important EPA regulations, this country could end up in a very serious crisis.

I ask you not to repeal key regulations, such as the Clean Air and Clean Water Acts. The Congressional Budget Office should be required to do an analysis of the collateral costs to any type of repeal that is proposed. You might find that there are "unintended consequences" to the ideology that regulations limit jobs or cost too much. What is your health to you? Would you like your well to be poisoned? Then don't poison mine.

text: The EPA should protect our health and the environment.
docAbstract: Executive Order 13777, issued 2/24/17, directs agencies to establish a Regulatory Reform Task Force to oversee the evaluation of existing regulations to make recommendations about potential repeal, replacement, or modification.

text:
Hello,
I am writing today to speak up in support of existing EPA regulations, which protect America's natural resources. I grew up on a small subsistence farm in Northwest Missouri, and my family taught me to respect and care for the air, water, soil, and critters all around us. For our children to thrive on this earth, it is incumbent upon our generation to look after the resources that we all rely on. The current EPA regulations (at least those that haven't already been sacked by the current administration and Congress) are vital! They ensure that we are collectively protecting our shared resources so that we can live!

I am in strong support of the EPA and the restrictions that it places on private business (as well as the government) in an effort to ensure that our environment is safe and life-giving to its inhabitants. Please do not pass legislation and/or regulation which loosens restrictions that currently keep our air, soil, and water clean and usable just for some short term political or financial gain. Americans are counting on the EPA! Invest in clean energies (wind, solar) and create jobs through those industries instead of sliding backward toward an even deeper reliance on our diminishing fossil fuel resources (coal, petroleum).

Please do not repeal existing regulations -- and please continue to put in place regulation that preserves the health of our natural resources for all Americans.

Thank you!

Pursuant to sections 1031 and 1032 of the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (Public Law 111-203) (Dodd-Frank Act), the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection (Bureau) is proposing to establish 12 CFR part 1041, which would contain regulations creating consumer protections for certain consumer credit products. The proposal generally would cover two categories of loans. First, the proposal generally would cover loans with a term of 45 days or less or loans with multiple advances if each advance is required to be repaid within 45 days. Second, the proposal generally would cover loans with a term greater than 45 days, provided that they (1) have an all-in annual percentage rate greater than 36 percent; and (2) either are repaid directly from the consumer’s account or income or are secured by the consumer’s vehicle. For both categories of covered loans, the proposal would identify it as an abusive and unfair practice for a lender to make a covered loan without reasonably determining that the consumer has the ability to repay the loan. The proposal generally would require that, before making a covered loan, a lender must reasonably determine that the consumer has the ability to repay the loan. The proposal also would impose certain restrictions on making covered loans when a consumer has or recently had certain an outstanding covered loan. The proposal would provide lenders with options to make covered loans without satisfying the ability-to-repay requirements, if those loans meet certain conditions. The proposal also would identify it as an unfair and abusive practice to attempt to withdraw payment from a consumer’s account for a
covered loan after two consecutive payment attempts have failed. The proposal would require lenders to provide certain notices to the consumer before attempting to withdraw payment for a
covered loan from the consumer’s account. The Bureau is also proposing to adopt official interpretations to the proposed regulation.

As a 65 year old woman, I see multiple ways that my environment is worse than the one I had growing up. I don't see fire flies anymore. I don't see bees anymore. The demise of these small creatures is, I think, the canary in the coal mine. If they can't survive in our environment, it is only a matter of time before larger organisms can't survive. I foresee the day when we can't pollinate our food crops and we purchase everything from overseas, where they either aren't so short-sighted as we, or they are further behind us in the destruction of the environment.

I am a pretty dedicated Republican, because I don't believe any civilization can survive that destroys its young. However, it doesn't make much sense to save the children and destroy the world they will be living in. -- bsm

text:
The EPA has long been important in guiding policies and procedures to protect the environment, people, and animals from dangerous natural and man-made events. The American public expects the EPA to safeguard us and not to fear political ramifications. Typically, the EPA is led by somebody fighting diligently FOR environmental conservation and protections. Never before have I known an EPA Administrator to have current law suits pending against the very agency he leads, which makes me question his ethics and commitment to serve the agency.

Mr. Pruitt, I have lived in rural America all of my life. It is beautiful, peaceful, serene. Fortunately for me, there has never been any industry, or man-made disaster, in my area...just rich farm land. Since I was a child, I have watched the beauty of nature, birds chirping in the big Oak tree out back, crickets chirping in the evening as if they were playing a symphony. Nature undisturbed. Do you know what that is like? Have you ever experienced the beauty and majesty of nature you see, smell, and hear? Green tobacco growing in fields that continues endlessly. Vegetable gardens that were large enough to sustain us and other family members throughout winters, because what you had, you gladly shared. Do you know what a good feeling that brings to you and to your family? All untouched...nature the way God gave it to us. No natural or man-made occurrences to take away the natural beauties still in my mind. But, not everyone enjoyed seeing nature untouched like I grew up with. Many Americans live with corporate dumping, toxic chemicals, hazardous waste, and so much more. The thought of not having the EPA to mandate clean ups, revitalizations, and impose fines against those deserving of them for punitive purposes, is a scary thought.

America's EPA is based on science; and, science is real. Global warming is real. A true American EPA leader would never deny this fact! In fact, they would support it and fight for it!! And, then there is the issue of the Clean Power Plan. This golden opportunity is a chance to reduce carbon pollution from the single largest source of U.S. global warming emissions. Mr. Pruitt, why are YOU trying to help destroy the EPA, our environment, our country...this is AMERICA? Many people and animals will die. Ecosystems will be destroyed. Not just in the United States, but around the world. The environmental damage is causing droughts and famines NOW! We see the environmental damage caused NOW!! People are struggling and dying TODAY!!!

WHAT WILL YOU DO? SUPPORT SAFEGUARDS!! Take a stand for us all and save the environment and the EPA by being a good steward of what you have been entrusted with...it is not just a job, but our future! DO NOT DESTROY IT! The EPA has a founding mission and that is to protect human health and the environment. WHAT WILL YOU DO?

docAbstract: Executive Order 13777, issued 2/24/17, directs agencies to establish a Regulatory Reform Task Force to oversee the evaluation of existing regulations to make recommendations about potential repeal, replacement, or modification.

text:
The importance of EPA's regulatory role in protecting our environment cannot be overstated, especially in the face of accelerated climate change. Not only should environmental regulations be kept in place, but they should be strengthened to protect clean water, clean air, human health, wildlife habitat, biodiversity, and endangered species.

EPA must regulate green house gas emissions more aggressively. In addition, the agency plays an important role in regulating the release of toxins and cancer causing agents, including industrial chemicals, pesticides, radon gas, and heavy metals contamination from mining. The agency should have the directive and funding to continue in its intended capacity of a strong oversight and regulatory agency.

Rescinding environmental regulations serves no one's interest except the bottom line of polluting industries. These rules are not "burdensome" to the American people, and EPA does not have a mandate from the public to eliminate them. What is burdensome and unacceptable, is a free for all for industry to pollute and poison our environment.

We don't have to go back too many decades to know what happens when industry is unregulated. The waters of the Cuyahoga River and the airshed above Pittsburgh are just two of the more commonly cited examples.

The EPA's role is not to create jobs, although jobs are created when the environment is protected. Businesses looking to start up, expand, or relocate do not choose communities that cannot offer basic amenities like clean water and air to their employees. Recreation and tourism-based industries especially rely on a healthy environment. Ironically, by mandating remediation of contaminated sites, such as abandoned mines, EPA could create many jobs in the clean up sector. I don't have access to these figures, but I am sure many of them are available.

2017 should have been a year in which proposed regulatory changes took the form of improving regulations to protect the environment. Instead, we have an administration and congressional majority bent on deregulating industry, gutting environmental regulations and laws, and introducing legislation harmful to communities and the environment.

I strongly oppose any attempt to overturn environmental regulations, and want to see an independent EPA restored that is unhindered by politicians with industry ties.
docAbstract: Executive Order 13777, issued 2/24/17, directs agencies to establish a Regulatory Reform Task Force to oversee the evaluation of existing regulations to make recommendations about potential repeal, replacement, or modification.

text:
The EO states:
The EO further asks that each Task Force "attempt to identify regulations that:
(i) Eliminate jobs, or inhibit job creation;
(ii) are outdated, unnecessary, or ineffective;
(iii) impose costs that exceed benefits;
(iv) create a serious inconsistency or otherwise interfere with regulatory reform initiatives and policies;
(v) are inconsistent with the requirements of section 515 of the Treasury and General Government Appropriates Act, 2001 (44 U.S.C. 3516 note), or the guidance issued pursuant to that provision in particular those regulations that rely in whole or in part on data, information, or methods that are not publicly available or that are insufficiently transparent to meet the standard of reproducibility; or
(vi) derive from or implement Executive Orders or other Presidential directives that have been subsequently rescinded or substantially modified."

I find the text very worrisome; why we need to create jobs that are detrimental to the environment and people's health? How cost and benefits are established in addressing point (iii)? Why regulatory reforms and policies are being generated in contradiction to current regulations and why the regulations are estimated to be in the wrong side of the equation? I agree that periodically, regulations should be reviewed if ineffective or unnecessary, reformulated accordingly and if unnecessary removed. However, the rational of the EO is not clear and open the door for a swift removal of important environmental and health protection regulations that in the long run will make the cost benefit ratio to plunge. This was absolutely unnecessary, EPA scientist and policy makers should be acting on point (ii) 24 x 7. The Executive branch should let science to scientist and focus on improve the welfare of our nation today and for the future generations. The DC pot needs to be stirred, but this is not the way.

text:
Docket ID No. EPA-HQ-OA 2017-0190
Clean air and clean water are crucial to the health of children and adults living in the United States of America. Moreover, clean air and clean water are essential abiotic components of healthy ecosystems that support plant and animal life as well as human life. As a biologist, parent and grandparent, I find it unacceptable for our country to reduce current regulations that are in place to protect the safety and quality of the water we drink and the air we breathe. If anything, some of those regulations should be should actually be strengthened. Most recently, lead-tainted water in Flint, Michigan and parts of the state of California have underscored the dangers of unsafe drinking water. My own state of Missouri has grappled with undesirable ambient air quality due to unacceptable levels of lead particulates and other pollutants. Poor quality of both air and drinking water affects our most vulnerable populations: young children and elderly people. The effects are particularly devastating for young children: For example, exposure to airborne lead compromises the developing nervous system and brain, leading to loss of IQ, learning disabilities and poor academic achievement that can persist into early adulthood and affect lifetime education and achievement.

It is unacceptable to reduce regulations that have been put in place to ensure the safety and quality of the air we breathe and the water we drink. A country that aspires to be "great" (President Donald Trump's preferred word) cannot and will not be "great" by placing more emphasis on growth and profiit at the expense of human health; the latter is imperative in order to accomplish the former! Human capital is our country's most important resource, and that human capital must be protected. Do not harm it by compromising the safety of our air and drinking water! PUBLIC HEALTH MUST COME FIRST!!

Respectfully submitted,
Ilene Follman
St. Louis, Missouri

If people and companies are too short-sighted and selfish to do the right thing, it is government's job to protect and preserve. Please continue to do your job.
docAbstract: Executive Order 13777, issued 2/24/17, directs agencies to establish a Regulatory Reform Task Force to oversee the evaluation of existing regulations to make recommendations about potential repeal, replacement, or modification.

text:
Clean water and air benefit our citizens and the entire world. Cutting 20 or 40% of the EPA's staff will not promote better conditions for us all. Nor will dispensing with regulations. This is another give-away to corporate interests who will injure everyone on this planet for the bottom line and their shareholders. Witness the tobacco industry followed by Exxon Mobile.

The public needs the government to stand up against powerful interests who will do them harm if left to their own devices!

text: As existing regulations are evaluated, please keep in mind that they were put into place for a reason - corporations and industries have proven in the past that they cannot be relied upon to regulate themselves.  The EPA has a responsibility to the American people to provide clean air, water, and soil and to ensure that profit-driven companies do not destroy our environment in their unrelenting chase of the almighty dollar.  I gladly pay my taxes to support these regulations and expect my government to support them as well.

text:
I am writing in support of this Citizen Petition from NJOY et. al. which requests the FDA issue final guidance to manufacturers seeking PMTA approval and that it extend the compliance deadline for submitting these applications by 24 months from the date the guidance is published.

If left unchanged, the FDA deeming regulations will take full effect in November of 2018 and severely impact consumer access to the diverse vapor market. Currently, there is no clear-cut path manufacturers can navigate to gain market approval. The costs associated with this process are, for the vast majority of vapor manufacturers, an insurmountable hurdle. As a result, 99% of the vapor industry will be shut down in less than two years unless compliance deadlines are extended and the application process is defined.

The FDA took seven years to finalize the deeming regulation that brought vapor products under the agency's authority to regulate tobacco. Yet, when the rule was finalized, manufacturers were only given two years to comply. At a minimum, the current compliance period ignores the amount of time required to perform the studies FDA has indicated it may require in order to grant market approval for a product.

Having a diverse range of vapor products on the market is critical in order to achieve the public health goal of helping smokers move away from smoking combusted cigarettes and toward low-risk alternatives. Several recent studies demonstrate that the variety of e-cigarette flavors and devices plays a vital role in helping people transition to a smoke-free nicotine product and improve their health. Access to a diverse market of low-risk tobacco and nicotine products must be preserved in order to maximize the public health benefit. If left unchanged, the application of existing tobacco regulations will whittle the vapor market down to only a few expensive products that will be out of reach for many smokers.

I urge the Commissioner to consider the full weight of this petition and accept the petitioner's request for final guidance and to extend the compliance deadline. Thank you for considering my comments on this matter. time!
docAbstract: OPEN

I would like to begin by sharing my personal story of my journey to finally quit smoking cigarettes. I smoked for over 17 years, and tried countless times and methods to quit. It wasn't until I tried vaping in January of 2013 that I was finally successful. I have not smoked a cigarette since I started vaping, and over the past 4 1/2 years I have weened myself off of nicotine. I vape now more as a hobby, but also to not go back to cigarettes. I would like to see this industry flourish instead of being heavily restricted and not as accessible as it should be.

I urge you to support the electronic cigarette as a most effective form of tobacco harm reduction.

I smoked for 38 years. But in 2012 with the use of vaping I was able to completely
stop smoking cigarettes in a 2 week period. I have not had another cigarette since then.
I had tried at least 10 times to quit smoking over the years, by different methods,
using the weaning method, and nicotine gum. But had been unsuccessful in stopping the deadly-nasty habit of smoking cigarettes. Then I found e-vapor and was finally successful in smoking cessation. Hurray, I was off those horrible stinky chemical laden
cigarettes finally! I feel so much better, my lungs are clear and I don't have that
horrid smokers cough anymore. And I don't smell like a nasty ashtray anymore.
Thank God for vaping! I have been smoke free for 5 years now. I use multiple eliquid flavors in my personal vaporizers.
I switch back and forth between these flavors and have done so over the past 5 years. I don't vape straight tobacco flavor or menthol flavor. I have no interest in vaping
a cig-alike ecigarette which contains plain tobacco flavor.
I prefer a vanilla- custard crme flavored ejuice primarily but I also like fruit and candy flavor ejuices. I use an advanced personal vaporizer to vape with, using a rebuildable, refillable atomizer tank on a box mod.
I am horrified that the FDA is seeking to take away my access to buying vaping
products such as box mods, rebuildable tanks, and flavored ejuices, because this
is what I use to vape with on a daily basis.
What will happen if this is suddenly taken away? I will face having to smoke nasty
and deadly cigarettes once again. Not just me, but the millions of other vapers who
have successfully stopped smoking via vaping. Plus the other people who smoke, who
have not yet had the chance to use vaping to help them get off the stink nasty cigarettes.
I have already lost the ability to purchase vaping supplies from my favorite vaping stores , who have shut down in the face of these strangling regulations from the FDA.
I have seen many good people ( small business owners) who own Vape businesses
have to cease their operations, thus losing their source of income.
It has made it difficult on me to try and purchase supplies to vape with.

text:
I am a Physical Therapist practicing in Michigan.
I have been practicing for many years in the home health environment.
Thank you for the opportunity to submit comments on the proposal to delay the effective date of the Conditions of Participation for Home Health Agencies.
I would like to commend CMS for its efforts to revise the CoPs for HHAs and I support the new requirements
In order to allow Home Health Agencies sufficient time to meet the new requirements I encourage you to delay the effective date of the CoPs by 6 months.
Delaying the effective date to January 13, 2018 will enable HHA to effectively and efficiently come into compliance with the new CoPs.
Thank you,
Ruth Haefner PT

I am writing to provide comments with regard to 9 CFR Part 201, Federal Register Number 2017-07361, posted on April 12, 2017. I urge the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) to let the Interim Final Rule on Competitive Injury to become effective on October 19. This long-overdue rule takes important steps to ensure that ranchers and farmers are treated fairly and have some safeguards against unfair buying and marketing practices from meatpackers.

text: Protect all our national monuments!  These lands do not belong to Trump, Zinke, or our greedy local politicians!   The destruction, or reduction, of land that belongs to all Americans and future generations, is not acceptable!   I live in Utah and Zinke did it hear the voices of the majority of Utahns!
Please leave the Grand Staircase Escalante exactly how it was created.

Please, please leave Escalante Grand Staircase as it is.
Please, please leave Bears Ears National Monument as it is.
Please, please do not allow Uranium mining in, at, or near the Grand Canyon.
These are places of natural wonderment and ancient history that should not be damaged.
Thank you.

We do not need mining near or on national monuments.  There is no reason to change the status of vital lands to keep America dedicated to growing its economy.  The sun and wind properly harnessed can provide more than we need to fulfill the power needs of our country.  Do not tamper with the American People's legacy.

The Grand Staircase-Escalante National Monument is vital for the preservation of the unique landscape, archeology and paleontology contained within the current Monument. Since the monument's dedication,
I have discovered many amazing wilderness areas like Buckskin Wash, The Wave and Coyote Gulch. The solitude, shear majestic beauty and geologic wonder of these areas deserves continued protection.
The entire monument contains Dinosaur artifacts that are continuing to fill in the pre history record with new fossil discoveries.
These lands and artifacts need to be preserved.
Please do not remove one square inch of this monument from it's current borders.

Sincerely,
Barry Sochat

Growing up in Utah I was fortunate enough to spend much of my childhood exploring the incredible red rock country of southern Utah. Many of our trips were to Escalante-Grand Staircase National Monument, located a short distance from a close friend's house in Teasdale. From when we first started visiting the area in 1992 to my visit last summer, the spectacular areas we love to hike (Calf Creek Falls, Boulder Mountain, the Burr Trail, and on and on...) have thankfully not changed much. However, the once tiny towns of Torrey, Boulder, and Escalante (not to mention Moab...) have grown substantially, with most of the commercial growth appearing to cater to the growing number of visitors to this spectacular region. Similarly, on a trip to Grand Gulch (in now- Bears Ears) last summer to explore Ancestral Puebloan ruins, I patronized restaurants, a grocery store, and gas stations in Blanding and Bluff, as I know many of my fellow adventurers do/will too.

As federal lands, all citizens have a stake in the management of these lands. Removing protections at the behest of a vocal and self-interested minority is clearly not in the best interest of most residents of this region, the state of Utah, and the Country. I demand that you not undermine the integrity of the visionary and extremely important Antiquities Act. President Roosevelt is rightly honored among our greatest presidents for his foresight, including his passage of the Antiquities Act - TR would no doubt be horrified by the complete capture of the Republican party by extraction industries and misguided (and hypocritical) sagebrush rebellion types. The Act was specifically intended to protect areas from short-term destruction and revoking the monuments would invite degradation of the region and set a horrible precedent regarding the long-term protection afforded all our National Monuments and National Parks.

With over 100 years of success, THE ANTIQUITIES ACT IS NOT BROKEN - SO DON'T CHANGE IT! An extensive public process occurred prior to the monument designations. Particularly with Bears Ears, the boundaries established in the National Monument very closely reflect the compromise that the Republican Utah delegation and Tribes/environmental/public access groups developed over many years of negotiations. To claim this was rammed through without with local input is disingenuous at best.

Please remember that there are more important legacies than the short-term economic bubble that would result from any proposed mining or drilling in the area. As a hiker, backpacker, climber, river rafter, all-around-outdoor-enthusiast, I have spent many thousands of dollars on outdoor recreation and in communities near the places I explore. At 31, I will hopefully have 50+ more years of adventure and investment in these areas with my children, who I know will love them as much as I do. It is my hope that they will be able to share these landscapes with their children in much the same condition that they are today.

Mr. Zinke:  Please leave Grand Staircase - Escalante Monument alone.  Everyone associated with Trump has diminished their reputations - or they are in the process of doing so.  Our national monuments should be protected into perpetuity.  Let your reputation, as well, remain unblemished from the stain of Tump by your decision to protect our national monuments.  Don't be taken in by a fool of a president - a truly mentally ill person.
